David Plunket]] | successor2 = [[Herbert Gladstone, 1st Viscount Gladstone|Herbert Gladstone]] | order3 = [[United Kingdom Postmaster General|Postmaster General]] | term_start3 = 7 November 1884 | term_end3 = 9 June 1885 | monarch3 = [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Victoria]] | primeminister3 = [[William Ewart Gladstone]] | predecessor3 = [[Henry Fawcett]] | successor3 = [[John Manners, 7th Duke of Rutland|Lord John Manners]] | order4 = [[President of the Local Government Board]] | term_start4 = 1894 | term_end4 = 21 June 1895 | monarch4 = [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Victoria]] | primeminister4 = [[Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery|The Earl of Rosebery]] | predecessor4 = [[Henry Fowler, 1st Viscount Wolverhampton|Henry Fowler]] | successor4 = [[Henry Chaplin, 1st Viscount Chaplin|Henry Chaplin]] | birth_date = {{birth-date|df=yes|12 June 1831|}} | birth_place = [[Battersea]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1928|04|19|1831|06|12|df=y}} | death_place = [[Kings Worthy]], [[Hampshire]] | nationality = [[British people|British]] | party = [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] | alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] | spouse = Lady Constance Reynolds-Moreton (d. 1929) }} '''George John Shaw-Lefevre, 1st Baron Eversley''' [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|PC]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] (12 June 1831 – 19 April 1928) was a British [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] politician. In a ministerial career that spanned thirty years, he was twice [[First Commissioner of Works]] and also served as [[United Kingdom Postmaster General|Postmaster General]] and [[President of the Local Government Board]]. ==Background and education== Eversley was the only son of [[John Shaw-Lefevre|Sir John Shaw-Lefevre]] and Rachel Emily, daughter of Ichabod Wright. He was born in [[Battersea]], and was the nephew of [[Charles Shaw-Lefevre, 1st Viscount Eversley]], [[Speaker of the British House of Commons|Speaker of the House of Commons]].{{cite web|title=George John Shaw-Lefevre, Baron Eversley|url=http://histfam.familysearch.org/getperson.php?personID=I68385&tree=Nixon|work=Family Search: Community Trees|publisher=The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|accessdate=22 November 2012}} He was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]] and at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]],{{acad|id=SHW849GJ|name=Shaw-Lefevre, George John}} and was [[Call to the Bar|called to the Bar]], [[Inner Temple]], in 1855.{{cite web |last=Lundy |first=Darryl |url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p23397.htm |title= thepeerage.com George John Shaw-Lefevre, 1st and last Baron Eversley |publisher=[http://www.thepeerage.com The Peerage]}}{{Verify credibility|failed=y |date=February 2013}} ==Political career== Eversley stood unsuccessfully as the Liberal candidate for [[Winchester (UK Parliament constituency)|Winchester]] in 1859 but was successfully returned for [[Reading (UK Parliament constituency)|Reading]] in 1863, a seat he held until 1885.{{cite book |last=Craig |first=F. W. S. |authorlink= F. W. S. Craig |title=British parliamentary election results 1832–1885 |origyear=1977 |edition= 2nd |year=1989 |publisher= Parliamentary Research Services |location=Chichester |isbn= 0-900178-26-4 |page=251 }} He carried a vote in [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] for arbitration of the [[Alabama Claims]] in 1868.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} He entered the government under [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord Russell]] as [[Lord Commissioner of the Admiralty|Civil Lord of the Admiralty]] in 1866, a post he held until the government fell the same year, and later served under [[William Ewart Gladstone]] as [[Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Trade]] from 1868 to 1871, as [[Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department]] from January to March 1871, as [[Secretary to the Admiralty|Parliamentary Secretary of the Admiralty]] from 1871 to 1874 and again in 1880, and as [[First Commissioner of Works]] from 1881 to 1885. He entered Gladstone's cabinet in November 1884 when he was appointed [[United Kingdom Postmaster-General|Postmaster-General]]. He relinquished the post of First Commissioner of Works in February 1885 but continued as Postmaster General until the Liberals lost power in June 1885. Eversley lost his seat in parliament at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1885|1885 general election]] and consequently did not serve in Gladstone's brief [[Liberal Government 1886|1886 administration]]. He was able to return to the House of Commons in April 1886 when he was elected for [[Bradford Central (UK Parliament constituency)|Bradford Central]] in a by-election, which constituency he represented until 1895.{{cite book |last=Craig |first=F. W. S. |authorlink= F. W. S. Craig |title=British parliamentary election results 1885–1918 |origyear=1974 |edition= 2nd |year=1989 |publisher= Parliamentary Research Services |location=Chichester |isbn= 0-900178-27-2 |page=79 }} He once again became First Commissioner of Works and a member of Gladstone's cabinet in 1892. When [[Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery|Lord Rosebery]] became Prime Minister in 1894 he was appointed [[President of the Local Government Board]], which he remained until the following year. In 1897 he was elected a member of the [[London County Council]] as Progressive for the Haggerston Division.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} He was sworn of the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]] in 1880{{LondonGazette |issue=24918 |date=28 December 1880 |startpage=6969 }} and in 1906 he was raised to the peerage as '''Baron Eversley''', of Old Ford in the County of London,{{LondonGazette |issue=27933 |date=20 July 1906 |startpage=4973 }} a revival of the Eversley title held by his uncle. He made his last speech in the [[House of Lords]] in 1913.[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/people/mr-george-shaw-lefevre hansard.millbanksystems.com Mr George Shaw-Lefevre] ==Other public positions== Eversley was also a Commissioner to negotiate a Convention on Fisheries with French Government in 1858, a member of Sea Fisheries Commission in 1862, President of the [[Royal Statistical Society|Statistical Society of London]] between 1878 and 1879 and Chairman of the [[Royal Commission]]s on the Loss of Life at Sea in 1885 and on the [[Royal Commission on the Depressed Condition of the Agricultural Interests (1894–1897)|Agricultural Depression]] between 1893 and 1896. In 1865 he co-founded the [[Commons Preservation Society]], becoming its first chairman and, in 1905, its president.Lord Eversley. ''Commons, Forests and Footpaths''. Cassell & Company, 1910, p. v. He was appointed a Bencher of the Inner Temple in 1882. He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 1899.{{cite web | url = http://royalsociety.org/dserve/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqDb=Persons&dsqPos=0&dsqSearch=%28Surname%3D%27shaw-lefevre%27%29|title = Library and Archive catalog|publisher= Royal Society|accessdate= 2012-08-03}} ==Family== Lord Eversley married Lady Constance Moreton, daughter of [[Henry Reynolds-Moreton, 3rd Earl of Ducie]], in 1874. They had no children. He died in April 1928, aged 96, when the barony became extinct. He is buried in the graveyard at St Mary's Church, King's Worthy. Lady Eversley survived him by a year and died in February 1929. It is interesting that one of his sisters, Maria Louisa Shaw Lefevre, can be identified as the anonymous author of "The Notebooks Of A Spinster Lady, 1878-1903", published by Cassell in 1919. In her notebooks she tells amusing stories of life in the upper classes of society in England at the time, makes candid observations of contemporary people and recounts jokes she heard told. She records that she attended the funeral of her good friend Augustus Hare in 1903. The book's editor, also unnamed, says she died in 1908. Reference to "The Times" lists her in its report on the funeral and the death records confirm she died in 1908. Another sister, [[Madeleine Shaw-Lefevre]], was the first Principal of [[Somerville Hall]]; and another Rachel married [[Arthur Hamilton-Gordon, 1st Baron Stanmore|Arthur Hamilton-Gordon]], son of the Prime Minister the [[George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen|4th Earl of Aberdeen]]. == Notes == {{Reflist|2}} == References == "The Notebooks Of A Spinster Lady", page 290, regarding her attendance at the funeral, and page 295 where the editor records that she died five years after 1903. The Times, 28 January page 10. "Among those present at the funeral...Miss Shaw Lefevre".
